There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether or not growth hormone deficiency is a cause of short stature in children with X-linked hypophosphatemia.
Therechicine appears to be effective in the treatment of primary biliary cirrhosis. However, there is insufficient evidence to support its use as an adjunct to other liver transplantation drugs.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether sulpiride is superior to other antipsychotic drugs in treating schizophrenia.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of mifepristone in combination with vaginal misoprostol for women undergoing medical abortion.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of aldose reductase inhibitors in the treatment of diabetic neuropathy.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of dexamethasone in the treatment of comatose patients with malaria.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the routine supplementation of pregnant women with vitamin A. Further trials are needed.
The available evidence does not support the routine use of statins in the treatment of patients with cardiopulmonary bypass. There is a need for further well-designed randomised controlled trials.

Therelanzapine is an effective treatment for amphetamine psychosis. However, there is insufficient evidence to support its use as an adjunct to haloperidol. Further research is needed to determine the optimal dose and duration of treatment for this condition.

Therebinafine is an effective treatment for the treatment of tinea capitis. It is associated with a higher incidence of adverse events than griseofulvin, but there is no evidence to support its use as a first-line treatment.
